tossups.text: This artist’s etchings depicting himself “open-mouthed” and “wide-eyed” functioned as studies for expressions in his renditions of Christ on the Cross and The Raising of Lazarus. This artist’s portrait of a “noble Slav” recalls his many portraits depicting himself in oriental costume. Self-portraits by this artist include one of him as the Apostle Paul and one in front of a pair of (*) circles. He also painted his son Titus wearing a monk’s habit. This artist used himself as the model for a depiction of the Prodigal Son in a tavern that, like many of his self-portraits, depicts his wife Saskia. For 10 points, name this Dutch artist of over 90 self-portraits, who also painted group portraits like The Syndics of the Drapers Guild and The Night Watch.
tossups.answer: Rembrandt van Rijn [or Rembrandt Harmenszoon van Rijn] <RK, Painting/Sculpture>

tossups.text: Krishna wrestles one of these non-primate animals for 28 days to recover the Syamantaka gem. Athenian girls play-acted as these animals during rituals at the cult site of Brauron. The Hindu king of these animals is named Jambavan. Another of them named Ungnyeo (“oong-nyuh”) was sealed into a cave with a tiger, and then transformed into a woman who gave birth to Dangun (“DAHN-goon”), who founded a nation. Zeus took the guise of (*) Artemis to rape a nymph who was turned into one of these animals by Hera after being expelled from Artemis’s entourage. The Korean creation of humanity features a female example of these animals. One of these animals was turned into a constellation when her son Arcas almost shot her dead. For 10 points, what animal did Callisto become before being set in the sky as Ursa Major?
tossups.answer: bears [accept specific varieties such as sloth bears or grizzly bears] <AR, Myths/Legends>

tossups.text: A wealthy character in this play promises to donate to charity if a man succeeds in playing “monkey tricks” on his brother. In this play, a man repeatedly rings a bell to silence a crowd during a speech lambasting the rule of the “majority.” This play ends as its protagonist claims that the “strongest man” is one who “stands alone.” A schoolteacher in this play refuses to translate a book from English for a newspaper edited by (*) Hovstad called The People’s Messenger. In its final act, Captain Horster loses his job before his planned voyage to America. In this play, the mayor Peter refuses to pay for the re-laying of pipes that lead from Morten Kiil’s tannery to the polluted town baths. For 10 points, name this Henrik Ibsen play in which the citizens vote to give Dr. Thomas Stockmann the title moniker.
tossups.answer: An Enemy of the People [or En Folkefiende] <NC, Drama>

tossups.text: This many reactants combine to form an amide in the Ugi reaction. A ring with this many total phosphorus and sulfur atoms is found at the center of Lawesson’s reagent. Cyclizing acrolein (“uh-CRO-lee-in”) creates a ring with this many members called oxetane. This is the smallest number of d electrons for which a complex can exist in either high or low spin states. This is the number of atoms in a face-centered cubic unit cell. A ring of this size distinguishes a class of antibiotics that includes (*) penicillin, which are known as beta-lactams. White phosphorus consists of molecules containing this many phosphorus atoms. When a central atom is bonded to this many ligands, it can take on seesaw or tetrahedral geometry. For 10 points, what is the atomic number of beryllium?
tossups.answer: four [or 4] <RN, Chemistry>

tossups.text: Panna Bhatt is angered by a production of this play at the opening of Bharati Mukherjee’s “A Wife’s Story.” This is the final and best-known play performed hilariously fast in a one-act parody by David Ives. This play’s third scene includes a rambling monologue in which a man sums up his sexual encounters with the line “She gives me a cigarette, my balls feel like concrete. Eh?” That monologue from this play is delivered to the timid James Lingk at a (*) Chinese restaurant, where the claim that people named Patel are “lonely” and “like to feel superior” is made by Dave Moss. An office is ransacked between this play’s two acts when, hoping to win a Cadillac, Shelley Levene steals the title leads. For 10 points, name this play centering on a competition between a group of salesman, written by David Mamet.
tossups.answer: Glengarry Glen Ross (The second line refers to Speed-the-Play.) <AR, Drama>

tossups.text: Arnold Goldstein developed a cognitive behavioral technique that seeks to alter this behavior amongst adolescents, called “replacement training.” A “general” model of this behavior that analyzes how it is influenced by the media was proposed by Anderson and Bushman. A 1939 paper by Dollard, Doob, Miller, Mower, and Sears proposed that this behavior is “displaced” onto new targets when it arises from (*) frustration. In a 1961 experiment, video recordings of models that differed in this behavior were shown to two different groups of children at the Stanford University nursery; one of the models that exhibited [emphasize] more of this behavior yelled phrases such as “Sockaroo!” For 10 points, name this behavior that children socially learned in a study by Albert Bandura, leading them to attack a Bobo doll.
tossups.answer: aggression [or aggressiveness; accept aggression replacement training or aggression-frustration hypothesis; prompt on violence or attacking; do not accept or prompt on “bullying”] <RK, Social Science: Psych>

tossups.text: An Australian missionary claims that the protagonists of this novel have “Satan in their eyes” after they read in reverse to her. This novel references Heart of Darkness in its discussion of an Englishman who has “gone native” in the abandoned “History House.” In this novel, a biracial child drowns during a boating accident shortly before policeman savagely beat a Communist who works for (*) Paradise Pickles & Preserves. This novel reflects the harm of the “Love Laws” when the title character is killed for crossing caste lines through his relationship with Ammu. At the end of this novel set in the village of Aymanam, the fraternal twins Estha and Rahel reunite in 1993 and commit incest. For 10 points, identify this Booker-winning debut novel by Arundhati Roy.
tossups.answer: The God of Small Things <AR, Long Fiction>

tossups.text: A bunch of blue diagonal lines pierce passengers in one entry in a triptych from this art movement set at a train station. A Precisionist artist from this movement who immigrated to the US created several paintings that show gray, metallic cityscapes through the arches of the Brooklyn Bridge. An artist from this movement painted the States of Mind triptych and acted on his desire to separate from “analytical discontinuity” by creating a sculpture that uses two separate blocks as (*) pedestals for a figure modeled on the Nike of Samothrace. The feet of a dachshund are blurred in painting from this movement titled Dynamism of a Dog on a Leash by Giacomo Balla. The sculpture Unique Forms of Continuity in Space is from, for 10 points, what mostly Italian art movement that celebrated war and technology?
tossups.answer: Futurism [or Futurismo] (The first clue refers to the painting Those Who Go.) <AR, Painting/Sculpture>

tossups.text: It’s not science, but this discipline’s central topic of study is likened to a boat repaired by sailors on the open sea in a metaphor proposed by Otto Neurath (“NOY-rot”). Defenses for “perpetual” and Christian forms of practice are provided by an approach to this field advocated by the philosophers William Alston and Alvin Plantinga, called its “reformed” variety. An approach to this branch of philosophy called foundationalism is one solution to the (*) regress argument. A common definition used in this field originates in the dialogue Theaetetus (“thee-uh-TEE-tuss”). Jones and Smith are discussed in one of the problems in this field named for Edmund Gettier (“GETTY-er”), which challenge the Platonic definition of its central concept as “justified true belief.” For 10 points, name this field of philosophy that studies knowledge.
tossups.answer: epistemology [accept reformed epistemology or Christian epistemology; prompt on philosophy; prompt on knowledge, philosophy of knowledge, or study of knowledge until “knowledge” is read] <WA, Phil/Thought>

tossups.text: The abundance of these particles was limited in 2017 by the MoEDAL experiment. Solutions to Yang–Mills field equations in SU(2) (“S-U-two”) known as merons behave like an example of these entities co-named for Yang. Two of these entities can be connected by a type of one-dimensional curve that is [emphasize] not gauge (“gayj”)-invariant and is called one physicist’s namesake “string.” These entities appear at singularities in the (*) vector potential. These entities exist if the electric charge is quantized according to a condition formulated by Paul Dirac. Incorporating these entities into Maxwell’s equations makes the equations fully symmetric. The statement that the divergence of the B-field is zero, alternatively known as Gauss’s law, implies that these entities do not exist. For 10 points, name these point-sources of magnetic fields, which are contrasted with the common dipole.
tossups.answer: magnetic monopoles [accept Wu–Yang monopoles or Dirac monopoles] <WA, Physics>

tossups.text: It’s not cloth, but Stephen Rockel wrote a book on the role of the Nyamwezi people as a “nation of porters” for this good. William Fagg coined the term “Afro-Portuguese” to refer to sculptures made from this good in the Kongo Kingdom for European consumption. It’s not slaves, but Tippu Tip became rich by extorting tribute in this good from Central African states and then reselling it. Along with bronze, this good was used to make royal altars in the (*) Benin Kingdom. The Sheldrick Trust was founded to combat the trade in this good, whose 1989 ban led to a recovery in the population of the animal it is derived from. For 10 points, name this good that was frequently imported from Africa for use in billiard balls and piano keys in the 19th century.
tossups.answer: ivory <JM, World History>

tossups.text: Dan Gibson is the best known exponent of a theory that Muhammad was actually from this city rather than Mecca. This city, called Rekem by its inhabitants, was the namesake of a Roman province whose capital was moved to Bosra after Trajan’s capture of this city. Believing that he would find Aaron’s tomb there, Johann Ludwig Burckhardt became the first post-classical European to visit this city in 1812. (*) Aretas IV, a king who ruled from this city, is best known as the namesake of a building in it known as his “treasury” even though it is likely his tomb. tossups.text: The CSRW in Boulder, Colorado, maintains a truck fleet, called this effect “on wheels,” which was deployed in Argentina for the RELAMPAGO project. Measurements based on this effect taken at different elevation slices are aggregated into a “volume coverage pattern” by the WSR-88D system, better known as NEXRAD (“nex-rad”). “Hook echoes” appear because the change in (*) phase due to this effect is greater when studying rapidly rotating mesocyclones. To study the movement of precipitation, meteorologists use pulse timing to detect position and use this effect to detect velocity. This effect is also exploited in “speed guns” used by police. A namesake form of weather radar takes advantage of, for 10 points, what effect that causes redshift, in which moving wave sources appear to have different frequencies?
tossups.answer: Doppler effect [accept Doppler on Wheels or Doppler shift or Doppler radar] <WA, Earth Science>

tossups.text: The art critic John Ruskin referred to this mountain as a “noble cliff” and included his own illustration of it in his book Modern Painters. This mountain lies across the Theodul (“TAY-oh-dool”) Pass from a mountain called a “little” version of this one. Like its (*) “Klein” counterpart, this mountain is in the Pennine (“PEN-nine”) Range. tossups.text: The nth eigenfunction given by the heat equation with Dirichlet (“DEE-ree-klet”) boundary conditions is this function of n, times a constant, times x over L. The union of “this function of one-over-x” and the origin is used to construct a space that is connected but not path-connected; that space is called the “topologist’s curve” of this function. In complex analysis, this function is defined as e-to-the-i-z minus e-to-the-negative-i-z, all over 2i. Like tangent, this function can be (*) approximated by the line y-equals-x for small values of x, according to the small-angle approximation. This function appears in the Fourier expansion of odd functions. The inverse of this function is the antiderivative of one over the square-root of “one minus x-squared.” For 10 points, name this trigonometric function whose derivative is cosine.
tossups.answer: sine [or sin; accept sine of x, with any letter in place of x, such as theta; do not accept or prompt on “sinh” or “hyperbolic sine”] <NC, Math>

tossups.text: A businessman based in this colony, Alfred Beit, co-founded a company whose interests led to this colony’s annexation of Stellaland. tossups.text: “Twisting” these objects allows processes to be predicted using crossing symmetry. Elements of the S-matrix can be calculated perturbatively by summing an infinite number of these objects in a Dyson series. Corrections to classical processes are treated with “one-loop” examples of these objects. The relative contribution of one of these objects to an interaction is inversely related to the number of primitive vertices it has. Some “virtual” entities are represented by (*) squiggly lines that begin and end within these objects. Their axes (“AX-eez”) represent space and time, with antiparticles being shown on them as moving backward in time. For 10 points, name these diagrams that depict quantum mechanical processes, which are named for an American physicist.
tossups.answer: Feynman diagrams <WA, Physics>

tossups.text: A map of this city produced in Italian by Sebastian Munster changed its city plan to a European-style grid. The “stone of the twelve angles” was an archaeological relic found in this city and exemplifies its builders’ common technique of cutting stones geometrically to do away with the need for mortar. This city is defended by the fortress of Sacsaywaman (“sock-say-wah-MAHN”), which forms the “head” of its (*) puma-shaped layout. This city marked the point of division into four “quarters” including Antisuyu and Collasuyu (“ko-la-SOO-yoo”). A temple called the Coricancha was one of the most important landmarks in this city and was used to worship the sun god Inti. This city was sacked after a loss at the Battle of Cajamarca (“ka-ha-MAR-ka”) for Atahualpa (“ah-tah-WALL-pah”). For 10 points, name this capital of the Inca Empire.
tossups.answer: Cusco [or Cuzco or Qosqo] <JM, World History>

tossups.text: Galen Strawson defended this philosopher’s view that identity depends on psychological continuity, and thus on “consciousness, not on substance.” Galen’s father Peter reused a term coined by this philosopher to describe both nominal and real essences, which cannot be measured. tossups.answer: John Locke <ML, Phil/Thought>

tossups.text: A king sacrificed nine sons to this god to extend his own life by 140 years, but his subjects understandably refused to let him sacrifice his tenth, so that king died of old age. This god, who received those sacrifices from Aun, is mocked by his own son for using the magic wand Gambanteinn in a flyting, or insult contest, in which this god appears as the ferryman Harbard. This god turned into a snake to slither through a hole drilled in a mountain by (*) Baugi (“BOW-gee”), thus gaining access to Suttung’s lair. By doing so, he sought to acquire a magic substance mixed with the blood of Kvasir, the mead of poetry. This god embalmed the head of Mimir, at whose well he sacrificed an eye to gain wisdom. The ravens Hugin and Munin belong to, for 10 points, what “All-Father” and chief Norse god?
tossups.answer: Odin [accept Wotan or Wuotan or Wodan or Woden] <ML, Myths/Legends>

tossups.text: A painting in which an angel holds this man’s hand as he writes in a book was reworked into a similar scene, in which this man rests his knee on a stool and hastily scribbles as he listens to an overhead angel. The artist’s earlier painting (*) The Cardsharps provided the basis for secondary figures in a tenebrist painting titled for this man in the Contarelli Chapel. tossups.text: A young Claude Debussy was “crushed” by living in this city after writing a cantata, though he completed the vibrant suite Printemps (“pran-TOM”) in this city. Berlioz left this city to kill his ex, and wrote the cantata Herminie (“air-mee-NEE”) in one of four attempts to live in this city. Half the cellos tune their lowest string down to B to play faint marching tritones before a slithery English horn solo right after a nocturne set in this city fades out a phonograph recording of a chirping (*) nightingale. In 1913, Lili Boulanger (“boo-lawn-ZHAY”) was the first woman to win a prestigious French scholarship named for this city. A tone poem trilogy set in this city depicts four “festivals,” and certain objects in the Janiculum (“juh-NICK-yoo-lum”), a catacomb, and the Villa Borghese (“bor-GAY-zay”). Ottorino Respighi (“res-PEE-ghee”) depicted the “Pines” of, for 10 points, what city’s Appian Way?

He used the character of Olympia to further an idea developed by Ernst Jentsch (“yench”) in an essay on E. T. A. Hoffman’s “The Sandman.” Detective fiction likely inspired this author of an essay on “The (*) Uncanny” to write about a boy who imagines a pack of wolves outside his window called the “Wolf Man.” An idea put forth by this author was inspired by a character who murders his father Laius in an Ancient Greek play, and was believed to be innate to all boys. For 10 points, name this Austrian thinker whose ideas influenced psychoanalytic literary criticism.
tossups.formatted_answer: Sigmund Freud [or Sigismund Schlomo Freud] (Mohsin Hamid’s book is Discontent and its Civilizations.) <RK, Misc Lit>

tossups.text: Every finite group is the group of symmetries of one of these objects by Frucht’s theorem. It’s not a table, but groups can be represented using one of these objects named for Cayley. Matrix representations of these objects include the Laplacian matrix and the adjacency matrix. Some of these objects called snarks contain a substructure named for Julius Petersen, which itself is a common counterexample. If one of these structures does not contain (*) K-sub-5 or K-sub-3-3 as a minor, then it is planar according to Wagner’s theorem. Euler (“OY-ler”) used these objects to solve the Bridges of Königsberg problem. Examples of these objects include bipartite and complete ones. For 10 points, name these mathematical objects consisting of vertices and edges.
tossups.answer: graphs [accept directed graphs or oriented graphs or digraphs; prompt on network or diagram] <NC, Math>

tossups.text: When a messenger sent by this goddess killed a pheasant, the arrow landed at this goddess’s feet, after which a god standing next to her got pissed and threw the arrow into the messenger’s chest, killing him. This goddess, who employs a three-footed crow as a messenger, sent her grandson from the plain of heaven across a bridge to become the ruler of earth. In one story, her curiosity was piqued by the sound of laughter from several gods watching a bad (*) striptease performed on top of a bathtub. When this goddess sent Ninigi to rule earth, she gave him three gifts: a precious jewel, a “grasscutter” sword, and a mirror thought to be kept at the Ise (“ee-say”) shrine in which she saw her own reflection after emerging from a cave. For 10 points, name this sister of Susano’o who is the Shinto sun goddess.
tossups.answer: Amaterasu [or Amaterasu-no-Omikami] <WA, Myths/Legends>

tossups.text: In “A Certain Tendency of the French Cinema,” François Truffaut (“true-FOH”) claims that a film of this title prompted the French to make Pépé le Moko in a “frank plagiarism of the American cinema.” That film of this title opens with screens asking “What are you going to do about it?” before segueing (“SEG-way-ing”) into a three-minute continuous shot, and was adapted from an Armitage Trail novel by Howard Hawks. Another film of this title cuts between shots of a man kissing a woman in a blue bikini in his car and of Angel’s face as he is (*) dismembered by a chainsaw. In that film of this title, a man asks “You wanna play rough?” before grabbing a grenade launcher and firing at Sosa’s men, yelling “Say hello to my little friend!” For 10 points, give this title of a 1983 Brian de Palma film that stars Al Pacino as a Cuban drug lord.
tossups.answer: Scarface <WA, Other Arts: Film>

tossups.text: The tail of a density distribution modelling one of these structures is often characterized by the “skin thickness,” across which that density drops from 90 percent to 10 percent. Danysz (“DAH-nish”) and Pniewski (“p’nee-EV-skee”) discovered one of these objects containing a hyperon. Maria Goeppert-Mayer (“GUR-putt-MY-er”) developed a model of these structures that allows for the prediction of a sequence of numbers characterizing them, including (*) 28, 50, 82, and 126. The motion of these objects is considered to be negligible in the Born–Oppenheimer approximation. The shell model describes these objects, which are particularly stable at “magic numbers.” The existence of these objects was deduced in an experiment in which alpha particles were fired at gold foil by Ernst Rutherford. For 10 points, name these structures composed of protons and neutrons.
tossups.answer: atomic nucleus [or atomic nuclei] <WA, Physics>

tossups.text: The chronicler Walter Bower exalted the “charming and witty eloquence” of this kingdom’s queen Ermengarde de Beaumont. Another queen of this kingdom was canonized as St. Margaret. A dynastic crisis in this kingdom resulted when Margaret, Maid of Norway, died at age 7. A queen of this kingdom lost public support after the murder of her secretary, David Rizzio, by her husband (*) Lord Darnley. This kingdom’s Covenanter sect led opposition to the introduction of the Book of Common Prayer, since some elements of it ran counter to the teachings of John Knox. This kingdom and its southern neighbor were jointly ruled by Queen Anne after the Act of Union. For 10 points, name this Celtic kingdom whose 16th-century queen Mary was imprisoned.
tossups.answer: Scotland [or Alba] (Bower wrote the Scotichronicon.) <NC, European History>

tossups.text: The final chapter of Camille Paglia’s Sexual Personae compares Emily Dickinson to this author’s wife, whose struggles are depicted in a Yukio Mishima play. A pamphlet telling his countrymen “Yet another effort… if you would become Republicans” appears in this author’s Philosophy in the Bedroom. This author and the Austrian novelist of Venus in Furs name two contrasting terms coined by Richard von Krafft-Ebing. A woman is struck by lightning after experiencing the “misfortunes of virtue” in this author’s novel (*) Justine. While imprisoned in the Bastille, this author wrote a novel about four wealthy libertines who retreat to a remote castle where they conduct violent orgies with imprisoned teenagers. For 10 points, 120 Days of Sodom was written by what Frenchman, who names the experience of deriving pleasure from inflicting pain?
tossups.answer: Marquis de Sade (“sod”) [or Donatien Alphonse François, Marquis de Sade] (The Austrian novelist is Leopold von Sacher-Masoch.) <RK, Misc Lit>

tossups.text: Every year during this holiday, people meet on Cole’s Hill to commemorate Frank James’s speech on it. On this holiday, a Coast Guard blockade was blocked by Ron Craig’s ship, allowing John Trudell’s people to pass. Creedence Clearwater Revival supported that protest on this holiday with the donation of a boat. The UAINE created a National Day of Mourning on this holiday. After a letter campaign by (*) Sarah Josepha Hale to Abraham Lincoln, this holiday became a national holiday in 1864. Traditionally, Native American groups have protested it by painting Plymouth Rock red or occupying a replica of the Mayflower. For 10 points, name this holiday, commemorating Squanto’s sharing of food, celebrated on the fourth Thursday of November.
tossups.answer: Thanksgiving Day [accept National Day of Mourning until read; accept Unthanksgiving Day] <ML, US History>

tossups.text: In 2018, this company was condemned after reports that it contracted the Lovelace Research Institute to conduct experiments on live Java monkeys. Three executives from this company were indicted in September 2019 for holding back market-moving information. For several years starting in 2009, this company programmed its TDI technology to recognize the EPA’s FTP-75 cycles, such that they would only activate controls in the laboratory and thus limit (*) engine output. As a result, those vehicles built by this company put out 40 times more nitrogen oxide in real life compared to during emissions testing, resulting in a scandal that brought down CEO Mark Winterkorn. For 10 points, name this German auto manufacturer whose former products include the Beetle.
tossups.answer: Volkswagen [prompt on VW] <WA, Other Academic>

tossups.text: This river is the ultimate drain of most of a highland region littered with many tabletop mountains called tepuis (“teh-POO-ees”). Competition from the spectacled caiman (“KAY-min”) has helped drive this river’s namesake species of huge crocodile to critically endangered status. This river’s name means “a place to paddle” in the language of the local Warao people, who travel on it in boats. The so-called Casiquiare (“ka-see-kee-AH-ray”) Canal flows [emphasize] south from this river into the (*) Rio Negro, linking it to a larger system to the south. This river provides most drainage to plains called the llanos (“YAH-nos”) and the rest of the area covered by the Guiana Shield. It empties into the Atlantic Ocean directly opposite from the island of Trinidad. For 10 points, name this major river of Venezuela.
tossups.answer: Orinoco River <WA, Geography>

tossups.text: Herodotus states that the Scythians sent one of these animals along with a bird, a mouse, and five arrows to Darius as a threatening gift. In one of Aesop’s fables, a stork begins devouring these animals after they pray to Zeus to receive a king. A mock-epic falsely attributed to Homer describes a battle between these animals and mice. These animals exclaim “That’s right, Mr. Busybody, right!” in a work that begins as a god argues whether he should complain about an aching shoulder or a bellyache with his servant (*) Xanthias. These animals sing and mock Charon while he rows in that play, repeating the line “Brekekekex koax koax.” Dionysus tries to retrieve Euripides from the underworld in an Aristophanes play titled after, for 10 points, what croaking amphibians?
tossups.answer: frogs [or batrachoi or ranae] <RR, Myths/Legends>

tossups.answer: Germania [or Germany] <JM, Ancient/Archaeology>

tossups.text: One of these dances in G minor by Franz Liszt begins with a steady crescendo as the left and right hand play presto triplets rising from the piano’s lowest register, and is part of a supplement to the second suite of Years of Pilgrimage. This dance is used in the finale of Schubert’s String Quartet No. 14, “Death and the Maiden.” This dance in 6/8 (“six-eight”) time, and the related (*) saltarello, are found in the finale of Felix Mendelssohn’s Symphony No. 4. This dance may be named for a city in Apulia whose women performed it furiously to sweat venom out of their pores. For 10 points, name this frenzied Italian dance whose name indicates that it could supposedly cure a hairy spider’s bite.
tossups.answer: tarantella [or tarantelle; or tarantello] <WA, Classical/Opera>

tossups.text: This letter is found in the prefix of the name of a molecule used as the starting point of heme and chlorophyll biosynthesis, called aminolevulenic acid, or ALA. Lactones and lactase with this letter preceding their name contain 6-membered heterocyclic rings. Lanthanide-based reagents such as EuFOD are used to improve the resolution of a quantity symbolized by this letter. That quantity denoted by this letter, which is often calibrated against a trimethylsilane standard, is called the (*) chemical shift and is vital in NMR. The addition of heat in a chemical reaction is symbolized by writing this letter over the reaction arrow. The lowercase version of this letter is used to represent partial charges in polar bonds. For 10 points, name this Greek letter whose uppercase version represents the change in quantities like free energy and entropy.
tossups.answer: delta <RN, Chemistry>

tossups.text: Subrahmanyan Chandrashekar proposed that this property could be found on the limbs of rapidly rotating binary stars with purely electron-scattering stellar atmospheres. The CMBR has two forms of this property resulting from either Thomson scattering in a heterogenous plasma or from gravitational waves from inflation. Those two forms of this property are known as E- and B-modes. The angle at which this property is transmitted perfectly between two (*) media with no reflection is equal to the arctangent of the ratio of their indices of refraction and is named for Brewster. This property, which comes in linear, circular and elliptical varieties, is employed by sunglasses to reduce glare. For 10 points, name this property that describes waves that have a particular direction of oscillation.
tossups.answer: polarization [do not accept or prompt on “polarizability”] <RN, Physics>

tossups.text: A 1988 paper by Patricia Wetzel discusses how male native speakers of this language are socialized to use language forms associated with women in English as part of a process of “becoming human.” Instead of syllables, this language’s phonology divides words into on (“own”), or poetry-based morae, including a single syllabic nasal. When writing this language’s native words, all long vowels except for i are marked with macrons in the (*) Hepburn romanization. This language marks location with the particles ni (“nee”) or de (“deh”), and it marks topics and subjects with the particles wa and ga, respectively. This language is related to the Ryukyuan (“ryoo-kyoo-in”) languages spoken further south. The copula marker desu (“dess”), meaning “it is,” is frequently used to end sentences in, for 10 points, what Asian language spoken on islands like Hokkaido and Honshu?
tossups.answer: Japanese [or Nihongo] <JM, Social Science: Linguistics>

tossups.text: For use in “The Dry Salvages (“sal-VAY-jizz”),” T. S. Eliot simplified this poem’s phrase “the deep / Moans round with many voices,” after calling it “too poetical” in his essay “Dante.” In this poem, the speaker notes “how dull it is” to “rust unburnish’d, not to shine in use!” and intends to “drink / Life to the lees.” In the second of this poem’s three stanzas, the speaker introduces his son, who “works his work” and is given the (*) “sceptre and the isle.” This poem opens with its speaker near a “still hearth (“harth”), among these barren crags, / Match’d with an aged wife.” This dramatic monologue ends with the speaker describing himself as “Made weak by time and fate, but strong in will / To strive, to seek, to find, and not to yield.” For 10 points, name this poem by Alfred, Lord Tennyson, spoken by a king of Ithaca.
tossups.answer: “Ulysses” <NC, Poetry>

tossups.text: A 2019 Science paper reported the kinase PfCLK3 as a novel drug target in members of this genus. It’s not trypanosoma, but members of this genus have around 60 var genes that they can switch on and off to express different versions of their PfEMP1 protein on host cell surfaces. In host cells, this genus undergoes 13 to 14 rounds of cell division in schizogony (“skizz-OGG-uh-nee”), which ultimately produces a multinucleate schizont (“SKIZZ-ont”). An unusual peroxide bridge is found in a sesquiterpene (“SESS-qui-TER-peen”) lactone drug that treats infection by members of this genus, called (*) artemisinin. The ovale (“oh-VAL-ay”), vivax, and falciparum (“fal-SIP-uh-rum”) members of this genus most commonly infect humans, and are all carried by the common Anopheles (“uh-NOFF-uh-leez”) mosquito. For 10 points, name this genus of eukaryotes that are responsible for causing malaria.
tossups.answer: Plasmodium <RN, Biology: Immuno>

tossups.text: An R-module Q has this property if every homomorphism out of a left ideal of R into Q can be extended to all of R, according to Baer’s criterion. In the short exact sequence consisting of maps from 0 to A to B to C to 0, the map from A to B has this property. To prove that a homomorphism has this property, f-of-x is set equal to f-of-y and it is shown that x must equal y. If m is greater than n, then a linear transformation from Rm to Rn (*) cannot have this property, which is equivalent to having a trivial kernel. A surjective map with this property is bijective. This property is required for an inverse function to have a unique output for every input. The function x-squared does not have this property because its graph fails the horizontal line test. For 10 points, name this property in which each output of a function is reached from exactly one input.
tossups.answer: injective [or one-to-one or injection] <NC, Math>

tossups.text: Jessie Little Doe Baird established a revitalization program for a language spoken in this state inspired by the success of Hawaiian “language nests.” The professors C. T. Huang and Ray Jackendoff were graduate students in this state, where they helped defend their advisor’s theories against the attacks of the “four horsemen” of linguistics. This state’s largest city is where the word (*) “wicked” is most commonly used as an intensifier, and has a traditionally non-rhotic accent that prominently uses the broad “a.” The unusually high rate of hereditary deafness on one island in this state led the islanders to develop their own sign language. The Wampanoag (“wam-puh-NOH-ug”) language is spoken in, for 10 points, what state where Noam Chomsky has taught at an “Institute of Technology” in Cambridge since 1955?
tossups.answer: Massachusetts [accept Massachusetts Institute of Technology] (The sign language is Martha’s Vineyard Sign Language.) <JM, Social Science: Linguistics>

tossups.text: This religion was practiced by a hereditary class of artisans known for their silver work called falasha. The Lemba people claim descent from followers of this religion. After marrying a follower of this religion named Zenobis, a queen legendarily adopted it and destroyed the Axumite Empire. Its followers stored thousands of documents in a cellar called the Genizah (“guh-NEE-zah”) in (*) Cairo. The Saadi dynasty of Morocco welcomed thousands of followers of this religion called marranos. A 1990 airlift allowed most of this religion’s Ethiopian followers to flee the country. Many Mizrahi followers of this religion lived in North Africa. For 10 points, name this religion practiced by Sephardic people who fled Spain, as well as Ethiopia’s Beta Israel people and Ashkenazis.
tossups.answer: Judaism [or Jewish religion] <JM, World History>

A third album by this jazz artist begins with a chord held on the organ by Joe Zawinul (“ZAH-vih-null”) on the track “Shhh/Peaceful.” (*) Wayne Shorter stayed on from this musician’s Second Great Quintet to work on that first fusion album by this musician, titled In A Silent Way. tossups.text: A factor required for this process is targeted by an antibody found in almost 100 percent of patients with mixed connective tissue disease. In Drosophila, the protein “suppressor of white apricot” is a regulator of this process, as are other members of the SR family. A complex involved in this process contains the Smith antigens. This process requires a donor site, an acceptor site, and a branch point, the last of which is required to form a lariat (“LAIR-ee-it”). In some substrates in which this process occurs without protein (*) catalysis, it proceeds via two successive transesterification steps. Small nuclear ribo-nucleo-proteins, or snRNPs (“snurps”) catalyze this process, which can produce alternative isoforms of a single protein. For 10 points, name this process in which introns are removed to form a mature mRNA.
tossups.answer: RNA splicing [accept alternative splicing] <EM, Biology: Genetics/Cell>

tossups.text: The largest munitions plant in the US during World War II was named for the mascot of this state’s flagship university and based in its city of Baraboo. Regulations on streams were waved for the recent construction of a plant near the town of Mount Pleasant in this state that, despite receiving 5 billion dollars in subsidies, will likely never employ anywhere close to 13,000 workers making LCD screens. In 2018, a large GM plant was demolished in this state’s town of (*) Janesville. Foxconn is currently building a huge plant in this state. Such companies as Pabst Blue Ribbon, Schlitz, and Miller have historically produced beer in this state’s largest city, leading to the naming of its professional baseball team. For 10 points, what state is home to former speaker Paul Ryan, as well as the Milwaukee Brewers?
tossups.answer: Wisconsin <JM, Geography>

tossups.text: A book by Oxford historian Stephanie Dalley posits that this location was actually hundreds of miles to the north of where it is traditionally placed. Berossus is the earliest historical source to mention this location, which was built in his original hometown. Sources frequently named this location after Queen Semiramis (“seh-MEER-uh-miss”), who actually lived at least 200 years before its construction. According to Strabo, an early version of Archimedes’ (*) Screw was built for use at this location. Archaeologists have yet to find this place, whose name refers to the trees that drooped over its terraces. The Chaldean (“cal-DEE-in”) king Nebuchadnezzar II built this location, which was among the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World. For 10 points, name this legendary green space in Babylon.
tossups.answer: Hanging Gardens of Babylon <NC, Ancient/Archaeology>

tossups.text: An artist claimed that his paintings of these objects were meant to create the “illusion of an endless hole” without “horizon or bank.” Several paintings of these objects were offered to that artist’s home country for a “monument to peace” to celebrate the end of World War I. An artist spent most of his last three decades of life painting these objects, which became more yellow and abstract over time due to his (*) cataracts, as seen in Le Bassin Aux Nymphéas (“luh bah-SAN oh nam-fay-AH”). A number of these objects are found beneath the title structure of an 1897 painting of a Japanese Bridge, which is among the over 200 paintings of these objects executed at the artist’s estate at Giverny (“zhee-vair-NEE”). For 10 points, name these aquatic flowers often depicted by Claude Monet.
tossups.answer: water lilies [prompt on flowers] <WA, Painting/Sculpture>

tossups.text: This is the musical form of a tintinnabuli piece for strings and bells whose theme is a descending A minor scale, Arvo Pärt’s (“pairt’s”) Cantus in Memoriam Benjamin Britten. The comes (“KOH-mays”) plays for a longer interval than the dux in examples of this form “by augmentation.” The “Quaerendo invenietis” (“kwye-REN-doh in-ven-YET-ees”) movement from The Musical Offering exemplifies a variety of this form in which an inverted melody accompanies the main theme, its “mirror” variety. In a piece (*) titled for this form, the descending notes [read slowly] “D, A, B, F-sharp” begin an eight-note ground bass ostinato. Nine movements in this form, starting “at the unison,” make up every third Goldberg Variation. If all voices in this form are identical, it is called a round. For 10 points, what form of imitative counterpoint titles a D major piece by Johann Pachelbel?
tossups.answer: canons [accept mensuration canon or canon by augmentation or mirror canon or Canon in D; prompt on rounds; prompt on imitative counterpoint until read; prompt on Cantus until read by asking “what is the form?”] <WA, Classical/Opera>

tossups.text: One of these devices is operated using the OpenQASM (“open-kasm”) software package. These devices can accomplish period-finding using the same methods proposed to solve Simon’s problem. These devices often map basis sets using mutually orthogonal matrices with Hadamard gates. Information used by these devices can be represented by a (*) Bloch sphere and can exist in superpositions when stored in their registers. These devices would be capable of breaking RSA encryption by running Shor’s algorithm. For 10 points, what machines can exploit entanglement for calculations, and as such are more suited for certain tasks than classical computers?
tossups.answer: quantum computers [or quantum supercomputers; accept quantum after “computers” is read; prompt on computers; prompt on qubits or quantum gates or quantum chips or QPUs or quantum processing units] <WA, Computer Science>

tossups.text: This author quipped a man should be able to “take a glass of wine by his own fireside,” referencing the burning of his theatre. This author, who acquired the Drury Lane theatre from David Garrick, used George Villiers’s The Rehearsal as the basis for a play about a rehearsal of the play The Spanish Armada. This author’s debut play, set in the town of Bath, failed due to the poor performance of the character Sir Lucius (*) O’Trigger. Lines describing “an allegory on the banks of the Nile” and “the very pineapple of politeness” appear in a play by this author in which Jack Absolute disguises himself as the penniless Ensign Beverley to pursue Lydia Languish, whose guardian is the comic Mrs. Malaprop. For 10 points, identify this Irish playwright of The Critic and The Rivals.
tossups.answer: Richard Sheridan [or Richard Brinsley Sheridan] <AR, Drama>

tossups.text: Over 1000 animals were thrown in a massive fox-tossing contest held in this city by one of its leaders, who founded a museum in this city called the Green Vault. After a 1685 fire, Matthäus Pöppelmann (“ma-TAY-us purple-mon”) helped rebuild this city by designing its Zwinger Palace. While fleeing Frederick the Great because he couldn’t actually create gold, the alchemist Johann Bottger discovered porcelain and began a factory near this city at Meissen (“MICE-in”). Bottger’s experiments were supervised by (*) Augustus the Strong, who led a state based in this city before becoming king of Poland. Arthur Harris of the Royal Air Force supported an attack on this city that Winston Churchill called a “mere act of terror.” For 10 points, name this capital of Saxony, a German city whose firebombing by the Allies was condemned as an atrocity during World War II.
tossups.answer: Dresden <NC, European History>

tossups.text: This thinker’s work was so interesting to Marie de Gournay that she became his “adopted daughter” and later translated many of his most famous works. This thinker claimed that humans have “more need for lead than for wings” to pioneer a method of contemplation. This thinker, who claimed that to study philosophy is to learn to die, wrote that eating a dead human is better than eating a live one in a work “On (*) Cannibals.” Another of his works defends a Spanish author’s Natural Theology. The motto “What do I know?” was used by this author, who pioneered a new form of writing in works like Apology for Raymond Sebond. For 10 points, name this provincial Frenchman who used the French word for “attempt” to name his Essays.
tossups.answer: Michel de Montaigne [or Michel Eyquem de Montaigne] <ML, Phil/Thought>

tossups.text: A polyomavirus that infects cells that detect this sense can trigger malignancy in its host when the helicase domain of its LT antigen is deleted. A sensor for this sense in crayfish was one of the first characterized examples of stochastic resonance in biology. The YbdG and Piezo channels transduct this sense. The carotid sinus and aortic arch are two locations that include receptors of this sense known as baroreceptors. Receptors for this sense are divided into (*) slow and fast-adapting and are innervated by A-beta fibers. Those receptors include Merkel cells and the onion-shaped Pacinian corpuscle. Receptors for this sense can be found in the stratum basale or within hair follicles. For 10 points, name this sense that is used to detect movement or pressure on the skin.
tossups.answer: touch [or stretch or mechanoreception; accept pressure until read] <RN, Biology: Medicine>

tossups.text: This dynasty once paid a mercenary army for each disembodied head, after which the mercenaries proceeded to massacre a bunch of this dynasty’s subjects to collect the bounty. That incident is recounted in Frederick Wakeman’s history of the transition of this dynasty to its successor, titled The Great Enterprise. This dynasty is postulated to have “discovered the world” by the pseudohistorian Gavin Menzies. Most silver mined in the Americas ultimately went to purchase (*) goods from this dynasty, such as from its official kilns at Jingdezhen (“jing-duh-jun”). Its Yongle (“yong-luh”) emperor supervised the creation of historical texts from a palace complex built under it, the Forbidden City. The eunuch (“YOO-nuck”) Zheng He (“jung huh”) sailed the seas on behalf of, for 10 points, what dynasty whose official history was written under its successors, the Qing (“ching”)?
tossups.answer: Ming dynasty <JM, Historiography>

tossups.text: After an invader was granted this title, he was ordered to kiss his overlord’s foot, but did so by bringing that overlord’s foot up to his mouth, thus making him fall over. That first man to hold this title, known in sagas as Hrólfr the Walker, was given it in exchange for agreeing to stop pillaging the lands of Charles the Simple. This title’s holders include a man born to Herleva, the (*) mistress of Robert the Magnificent, and a Viking of unknown birth named Rollo. Another holder of this title was nicknamed “the bastard” and defeated an exhausted rival who had just won the Battle of Stamford Bridge in an engagement on Senlac Hill. For 10 points, identify this specific title of nobility held by the winner of the Battle of Hastings, William the Conqueror.
tossups.answer: Duke of Normandy [prompt on duke or other answers that indicate a ruler of Normandy] <JM, European History>

tossups.text: A set of ancient treatises named for this concept state that its principles should be learned during brahmacharya (“BRAH-muh-CHAR-yuh”), the first of the four ashramas (“ASH-ruh-muhs”). In a story illustrating this concept, Yudhisthira (“YOO-dish-teer”) refused to enter heaven without his loyal dog, who was actually a god named for this concept in disguise. Much like Hindus, many Buddhists use the word for this concept as an alternate name for the king of the narakas, who is otherwise named Lord (*) Yama, or death. This concept, which is often represented by an eight-spoked wheel, is exemplified by the obligations that arise on account of one’s varna, or caste. In general, it refers to that which is consistent with rta (“RR-tuh”), or the order of the universe. For 10 points, give this Sanskrit term that is often translated as “duty” or “law.”
tossups.answer: dharma [accept dharmachakra or wheel of dharma] <WA, Religion>

tossups.text: Biosynthesis of this molecule is commonly studied in the bacterium Komagataeibacter xylinus. The amount of this molecule can be quantified by mixing it with anthrone and calculating its absorbance at a wavelength of 635 nanometers. A bright blue solution of tetra-ammine-di-aqua-copper(II), or Schweizer’s reagent, is commonly used to dissolve this polymer. Proteins are transferred onto a membrane of PVDF or a nitrated derivative of this polymer in a (*) western blot. Carbon disulfide is used in xanthation, one step of a process in which this polymer is converted into rayon fibers. This polymer is composed of D-glucose monomers joined by beta 1,4 linkages. For 10 points, name this polysaccharide that comprises the cell walls of plants.
tossups.answer: cellulose <RN, Chemistry>

tossups.text: EGLN proteins catalyze the addition of this functional group onto HIF-1alpha to mark it for ubiquitination. Triethylaluminum catalyzes the oligomerization of ethylene in a process used to produce fatty versions of this functional group named for Ziegler. Cumene hydroperoxide undergoes a Hock rearrangement in an industrial process used to add this functional group to (*) benzene. This functional group has a broad IR peak at 3000 inverse centimeters due to hydrogen bonding. Pyridinium chlorochromate can be used instead of a Jones reagent when one wishes to oxidize this functional group into an aldehyde instead of a carboxylic acid. For 10 points, name this functional group written as OH.
tossups.answer: hydroxyl [or alcohol; accept fatty alcohol or Ziegler alcohol] <RN, Chemistry>

tossups.text: Both a 2011 debut novel by Madeline Miller and Pat Barker’s 2018 novel The Silence of the Girls are inspired by this work, which was translated in 2015 by Caroline Alexander. Sitting Bull’s secretary Catherine Weldon appears in a retelling of this work in which a beautiful woman flaunts a yellow dress stolen from the wife of a Major who owns a pig farm. A stand-in for this work’s author named Seven Seas sings “African babble” at Ma Kilman’s (*) No Pain Café in a retelling of it set on St. Lucia (“LOO-sha”) by Derek Walcott. The first-known use of ekphrasis was this poem’s description of a warrior’s shield. The Catalogue of Ships appears in this epic poem, which opens by describing the “black and murderous” rage of Achilles. For 10 points, the Trojan War is the subject of what Homeric epic?
tossups.answer: Iliad (Madeline Miller’s novel is The Song of Achilles.) <RK, Misc Lit>

tossups.text: The Osogbo sacred grove in Nigeria is home to several mysterious sculptures made of this material with human faces. On his tobacco farm, art dealer Tom Blomefield established a workshop to train artists using this material, including Henry Munyaradzi (“moon-ya-RA-dzee”), an important figure in the “Shona” school. Many African artworks were made of the “tiger’s eye” variety of this material. Churches in the (*) Ethiopian city of Lalibela are built from single pieces of this material. Another variety of this material was used to make the bird statues found at Great Zimbabwe. tossups.text: This city was the center of a movement of squatters who took over the property of former state-owned enterprises in the 1990s and formed collectives like Tacheles (“TA-khuh-liss”) in its Mitte (“MIT-uh”) neighborhood. This city’s first gay mayor coined a slogan referring to it as “poor but sexy.” A popular shopping district in this city is known by the shortened name “Ku’damm” (“KOO-dom”). Two bordering neighborhoods lend their names to a nightclub in this city called Berghain (“BAIRG-hyne”). A huge (*) concrete cylinder in this city was built to test whether its swampy soil on the river Spree could support a triumphal arch, as part of Albert Speer’s plan to turn it into a “world capital.” This city’s Tempelhof Field was converted to a park after this city’s airport relocated to Tegel (“TAY-gull”). For 10 points, name this city whose East and West halves were reunited in 1990.
tossups.answer: Berlin [accept East Berlin] <JM, Geography>

tossups.text: This island’s only ever king was a German mercenary who ruled for only seven months in 1736, later tried to mortgage it to British creditors, and was named Theodor von Neuhoff. Female suffrage was implemented on this island by the constitution of its namesake republic, which was declared in 1755 and issued coins depicting its traditional Moor’s Head symbol. That republic ended this island’s longstanding control by the city of (*) Genoa and was led by Pasquale Paioli (“pa-SKWAH-lay pie-OH-lee”) until it was conquered by the troops of Louis XV in 1769. This island’s most famous resident, born in that same year, executed a coup on the Eighteenth Brumaire and issued a namesake “code” reforming French law. Napoleon Bonaparte was born on, for 10 points, what Mediterranean island controlled by France, a smaller neighbor of Sardinia?
tossups.answer: Corsica [or Corse] <WA, European History>

tossups.text: This composer embraced Christian Science in New York, where he ran into clarinetist Simeon Bellison, whose klezmer band Zimro (“ZIM-raw”) just toured the Far East and contained a string quartet and piano; Bellison sent this composer a notebook of Hebrew themes that he quickly worked into an Overture for them. Before finishing a ballet with four seasonal fairies, he extracted three piano pieces from it, including a plucky, chromatic gavotte. His Symphony No. 1 in D major, scored entirely in concert pitch, imitates (*) Haydn’s style and also includes a brief gavotte with “wrong notes.” Galina Ulanova premiered the title roles of his Cinderella and a ballet whose three suites include “Dance of the Knights” and “Death of Tybalt.” For 10 points, what composer of the “Classical Symphony” returned from exile to Soviet Russia and wrote Romeo and Juliet and Peter and the Wolf?
tossups.answer: Sergei Prokofiev (The first clue is about Overture on Hebrew Themes.) <OL, Classical/Opera>

During this century, a ruler commissioned an automaton that depicted a tiger mauling a British soldier after winning a war in which he used iron-tipped rockets. During this century, the Afghan leader Ahmad Shah Durrani invaded India and clashed with the Maratha Confederacy. A casus belli arose in this century when the (*) Nawab of Bengal, Siraj ud-Daulah, killed 123 British prisoners in the “Black Hole of Calcutta” incident. In this century, Robert Clive won the Battle of Plassey, thus cementing the East India Company’s rule over Bengal. For 10 points, name this century in which Mysore fought Britain during the Indian theater of the American Revolution.
tossups.answer: 18th century [or 1700s] <JM, World History>

tossups.text: G. W. F. Hegel (“HAY-gull”) wrote that the “sound doctrine” of this thinker’s works was far inferior to Cicero’s De Officiis (“day oh-FEE-chee-eese”) and that the “reputation” of his works would be better “had they never been translated” by French priests. This philosopher claimed that the purpose of his teachings was to produce “profound persons,” and used a term for the sons of princes to designate those people. This man’s grandson wrote The Doctrine of the Mean, which is one of the (*) “Four Books” of this man’s teachings. Interactions of friend to friend, elder brother to younger brother, father to son, husband to wife, and ruler to ruled comprise this thinker’s “five relations.” His namesake philosophical system advocates filial piety. The Analects is by, for 10 points, what Chinese philosopher who praised obedience?
tossups.answer: Confucius [or Kong Fuzi or Master Kong] <WA, Phil/Thought>

tossups.text: The main symbol of the revivalist religion Romuva is one of these objects from Baltic folklore called Austras koks in Latvian. St. Boniface supposedly destroyed one of these objects sacred to Donar. A character named “Just-as-High” describes a daily tribunal held near one of these objects, which is frequently assaulted by four harts. That one of these objects is next to the well of fate, or (*) Urd, whose denizens pour sand and water on it daily. The Norns care for one of these objects that is constantly gnawed on by the dragon Niddhogg. That one of these objects connects Muspelheim, Asgard, and seven other realms. For 10 points, name this type of natural object thought by many people to be the center of the world, such as the Norse Yggdrasil, which is an ash.
tossups.answer: world trees [accept tree branches; accept oak trees or ash trees] <WA, Myths/Legends>

tossups.text: A methyltransferase that acts on these molecules creates an m1A58 site. A group of enzymes that act on these molecules have designations like ZO, PL-7, and Jo-1 when they appear on a myositis antibody panel. Half of all mitochondrial mutations causing disease are for genes coding these molecules. Pseudouridine is found in the T-psi-C (*) arm of these molecules, which can also contain inosine near their 5-prime end. These adaptor molecules are charged by synthetases. They have an anticodon loop that can undergo wobble base pairing, and they initially go to the A site. For 10 points, name these cloverleaf-shaped molecules that carry amino acids to the ribosome during translation.
tossups.answer: tRNA [or transfer RNA or transfer ribonucleic acid; prompt on RNA or ribonucleic acid; do not accept or prompt on “DNA” or “deoxyribonucleic acid”] <EM, Biology: Genetics/Cell>

tossups.text: A short piece in this genre by Dmitri Shostakovich parodies a march in 7/8 (“seven-eight”) time and Hanon exercises in its final themes and was written for his son’s 19th birthday. Apocryphally, a blind Ukrainian beggar’s tune provided the first theme of another Russian piece in this genre that opens with the unrecapitulated motif [read slowly] “F, D-flat, C, B-flat” played by loud horns. Vladimir Horowitz popularized a challenging D minor piece in this genre written the same year as the composer’s tone poem The (*) Isle of the Dead. Low F’s alternate with eight crescendoing block chords, often described as “bell-like,” to open the second piece in this genre by Sergei Rachmaninoff. tossups.answer: piano concerto [or piano concerti; prompt on concerto] (The second sentence describes Tchaikovsky’s Piano Concerto No. 1.) <WA, Classical/Opera>

tossups.text: An admissible decision rule based on this theorem determines the risk function by using a fixed weighted average as the expected loss. A naive classifier trained on a batch of emails exploits this theorem to filter spam. Prior distributions are multiplied by likelihood functions to give posterior distributions in this theorem’s namesake method of inference, which is contrasted with frequentism. tossups.text: This effect is encoded by the negative f u term in the horizontal momentum equation. To prevent it from contributing higher-order terms, this effect is assumed to vary linearly along the beta-plane. When this effect is assumed to be equal and opposite to the PGF, wind blows parallel to isobars; that approximation is useful at the synoptic scale and is called geostrophic. When this phenomenon combines with drag, Ekman (*) spirals result, in which a rotating column of water moves at an angle to the wind. Its namesake parameter equals the sine of the latitude times twice the Earth’s rotation rate. This phenomenon explains why hurricanes rotate counter-clockwise in the Northern Hemisphere, but clockwise in the Southern Hemisphere. For 10 points, name this effect caused by Earth’s rotation, in which objects deflect to the right in the Northern Hemisphere.
tossups.answer: Coriolis effect [or Coriolis force] <JZ, Earth Science>

tossups.text: Merchants would dress a slave up and have him impersonate this god for forty days prior to this god’s festival. A wingspan of more than 10 meters was possessed by a giant pterosaur (“TAIR-oh-saur”) named for this god from the late Cretaceous Period. This god stole cacao beans from his brother, after which he taught the secrets of making chocolate to humanity, which he earlier created after going to the underworld and stealing jade (*) bones. This god immolated himself and became the planet Venus after sleeping with his sister. He was often personified as a man with white skin and hair who sailed away to the east on a raft of snakes and is the twin of the dog-headed Xolotl (“sho-LO-tull”). Hernán Cortés may have been confused by some Aztecs with, for 10 points, what Aztec feathered serpent?
tossups.answer: Quetzalcoatl <WA, Myths/Legends>

tossups.text: This man is the primary prophet of a religion whose scriptures are called the “Great Treasury” or Ginza Rba (“geen-ZAH ruh-BAH”) and describe several emanations of God, including Abatur. This man, whom Muslims believe was buried in Nablus, is the main prophet of a Gnostic religion from Iraq called Mandaeism (“man-DAY-ism”). Though nobody in his family had this man’s name, his father wrote it on a tablet after being (*) deprived of speech during the three days before this man was born. This man, who performed the act for which he is most famous at the village of Bethabara, was born to Elizabeth and Zechariah and is referred to as the “forerunner” of Jesus. For 10 points, name this figure who acquired his sobriquet from dunking Jesus in the River Jordan.
tossups.answer: John the Baptist [or Yahya; or Yochanan] <WA, Religion>

tossups.text: This place is not Thebes, but an epic poem by Statius was the first to relate a story in which a “Carpathian seer” tells a woman to take the poem’s title hero to this place. Because a goddess who shares her name with this place fought on Zeus’s side in the Titanomachy (“Titan-AW-muh-kee”), her children Zelos, Cratos, Bia, and Nike are always near Zeus. The spread of a Greek belief regarding this place is tracked by numismatic findings of one-sixth of a drachma. Inviolable (*) oaths were sworn at this place by the Olympians. Thetis held her son by the heel while attempting to dip her son into this place and grant him invincibility. To ensure passage across this place, ancient Greeks buried the dead with an obol, or coin, under their tongue. Charon ferries people across, for 10 points, what river that surrounds the underworld?
tossups.answer: Styx [or The River Styx; prompt on underworld or Hades] <AA, Myths/Legends>

tossups.text: Since this artwork is found next to the Church of Saint Agnes designed by one of its artist’s rivals, one of its figures is often said to be shielding its eyes from the architectural horror of the church. That figure in this artwork is a Native American who lies on top of a pile of coins. Another of this work’s title figures is an old man whose head is covered by a cloth, symbolizing the fact that a certain (*) source was unknown at the time. A copy of the Pamphili family obelisk protrudes from this sculpture in the Piazza Navona, which allegorizes bodies found on Asia, America, Africa, and Europe. For 10 points, name this fountain sculpted by Gian Lorenzo Bernini that personifies the Nile, Danube, Ganges, and Rio de la Plata.
tossups.answer: Fountain of the Four Rivers [or Fontana dei Quattro Fiumi] <RR, Painting/Sculpture>

tossups.text: It’s not in South America, but several states that bordered this colony allied with Admiral Cornelis Jol (“cor-NAY-liss YOLE”), who briefly annexed it as part of the Groot Desseyn (“kh’ROTE duh-SIGN”) plan by the Netherlands. This colony was greatly enlarged in the 1700s when it annexed the lands of the Ovimbundu people. A neighbor of this colony invaded it in Operation Savannah. This colony initially had a separate constituent part named for the port of (*) Benguela (“ben-GWAY-lah”). Holden Roberto’s FNLA and Agostinho Neto’s (“ah-goosh-TEEN-yoo NET-oo’s”) MPLA fought for the independence of this colony, which was the primary source of slaves for Brazilian plantations controlled by the same colonial power. For 10 points, name this Portuguese colony whose successor state’s capital is Luanda.
tossups.answer: Portuguese Angola <JM, World History>

tossups.text: The defeat of this group is commemorated by the Lajkonik (“lie-CON-eek”) festival, which remembers a war in which this group counted their kills by filling nine sacks with right ears. King Béla IV of Hungary weakened his position before a battle with this group by expelling the Cumans, who had themselves fled this group’s advances. A crusade against this group was proposed after their victory at the Battle of (*) Legnica (“leg-NEET-sah”). The death of a leader of this group caused their general Subotai to retreat from Vienna in order to elect a new one. Those elections, the kurultai, were described in a Secret History of this group. This group was founded by a man with the birth name Temüjin. For 10 points, name this group that invaded Europe under Batu Khan and were founded by Genghis Khan.
tossups.answer: Mongols [accept Tatars or Golden Horde or Ulus of Jochi; accept The Secret History of the Mongols; do not accept or prompt on “Kipchaks”] <ML, European History>

tossups.text: Like rhenium and gold, this element forms a heptafluoride that is a strong oxidizing agent. This is the heavier element taken up by a symporter that is inhibited by the pertechnetate (“per-TEK-nuh-tate”) ion. This element’s methyl derivative reacts with a square planar iridium complex in the first step of the Cativa process. One isotope of this element decays by electron capture to tellurium-123, a reaction used in SPECT imaging. An ionic compound of this element and silver is used in both cloud seeding and photographic film. The (*) triatomic form of this element reacts with starch to form a purple complex, a phenomenon that is used in a popular clock reaction and Lugol’s test. Of the elements that are diatomic at STP, this element is the heaviest. For 10 points, name this halogen that is added to salt to prevent goiter.
tossups.answer: iodine [prompt on I] <RN, Chemistry>

tossups.text: In 2019, this constant was redefined such that the fine-structure constant equals [read slowly] “this quantity, times c, times e-squared, all over two times Planck’s constant.” The product of this quantity with the speed of light equals approximately 377 ohms. This constant’s units are equivalent to [read slowly] “seconds squared, divided by farads times meters,” as can be shown by rearranging Maxwell’s formula. This constant can be experimentally measured by finding the force between two wires of known length, current, and separation. It used to equal exactly (*) 4 pi times 10-to-the-negative-7 henries per meter. The current enclosed by a loop of wire, times this constant, equals the line integral of the B-field along that loop by Ampère’s circuit law. For 10 points, name this constant symbolized “mu-nought” that gives the ability of a vacuum to support a magnetic field.
tossups.answer: magnetic permeability [or vacuum permeability; or permeability of free space; or mu-nought; accept magnetic constant until “constant” is read, but prompt after; prompt on mu until “mu-nought” is read; do not accept or prompt on “permittivity”] <WA, Physics>

tossups.text: According to a namesake principle of functional analysis, pointwise-bounded linear operators on a Banach (“BAH-nuck”) space have this type of boundedness. A sequence of functions converges in the infinity norm if the sequence has this type of convergence, which is defined by the existence of a natural number capital N that depends only on epsilon, not on a point x. This type of continuity implies pointwise continuity. The CDF of a distribution named for this word is (*) linear between its two parameters, and its variance equals b-minus-a squared over twelve. Computing a probability using this distribution is often equivalent to finding the area of a rectangle because the density function is the constant function “one over b-minus-a.” For 10 points, rolling a die exemplifies the discrete form of what distribution in which each outcome has the same probability of occurring?
tossups.answer: uniform [or uniformly; or uniform distribution; or uniform convergence; or uniform continuity] <NC, Math>

tossups.text: This city returned to its historic Republican control in 2013 after its mayor was caught sexually assaulting veterans at a conference on sexual assault in the military, after which he resigned in disgrace. Bob Filner was mayor of this city, where Sarah Jacobs’ primary campaign was funded by a donation of 1.5 million dollars by her grandfather Irvin, the head of local industrial giant Qualcomm. In Congress, Darrell Issa (“ICE-uh”) long represented this city. Trucks enter this city from the south via (*) Otay Mesa (“OH-tie MAY-suh”), the southern terminus of highway I-5. Comic-Con takes place in this city. It is home to the busiest port of entry in the US, which links El Chaparral with San Ysidro and is the site of more ICE deportations than any other such port. For 10 points, name this city across the border from Tijuana, the southernmost on the California coast.
tossups.answer: San Diego <WA, Other Academic>

tossups.text: The Buddha is often shown raising one of these objects in an action called “fearless” or abhaya during encounters with an elephant. A motto called the Parasparopagraho Jivanam (“PAR-us-PAR-oh-PA-gruh-ho JEE-vuh-num”) is often found below one of these objects in a symbol adopted on the 2500th anniversary of the nirvana of Mahavira. This is the most common object that, prior to a Hindu wedding, is decorated with mehndi or (*) tattoos. These objects are used to make mudras. One of them with a wheel on it is used both as a symbol of ahimsa and of Jainism in general. In many Indian religions, these body parts are manipulated during meditation into wheel-like shapes to channel energy. For 10 points, give these body parts used to make gestures.
tossups.answer: hands [prompt on arms until “ahimsa” is read] <WA, Religion>

tossups.text: An archaeologist from this country found massive statues of Aramean royalty at the site of Tell Halaf, which he spent much of his life excavating. Another archaeologist from this country funded his expeditions by selling gunpowder to the Russian army during the Crimean War. That archaeologist from this country destroyed much of his most famous discovery due to his fondness for using dynamite to excavate. The (*) Pergamon Altar is controversially kept in a museum in this country’s capital. Another archaeologist from this country targeted a mound at Hisarlik for excavation and found the Death Mask of Agamemnon. For 10 points, Troy was excavated by Heinrich Schliemann, an archaeologist from what country?
tossups.answer: Germany [or Federal Republic of Germany or Bundesrepublik Deutschland] <JM, Ancient/Archaeology>

tossups.text: This composer had a piccolo quote the Andante movement of one of his own symphonies during an aria about a ploughman in spring. Another choral piece by this composer opens in C minor with a loud, held tutti C before a quiet, harmonically ambiguous flattened submediant triad. Later in that piece by this composer, soft pizzicato strings precede a loud, radiant C major chord on the word “Licht,” or (*) “Light.” Gottfried van Swieten (“SVEE-tin”) wrote the libretto for this composer’s The Seasons, as well as his oratorio beginning with a “Representation of Chaos” depicting the early universe. A timpani stroke in bar 16 of the second movement accompanies a sudden dynamic change in this composer’s Symphony No. 94 in G major, written in London. For 10 points, name this composer of The Creation and the “Surprise” Symphony.
tossups.answer: Joseph Haydn [or Franz Joseph Haydn] <WA, Classical/Opera>

tossups.text: A passage in this novel compares love to the sea, since “it’s uh movin’ thing” and “it’s different with every shore.” This novel opens by noting how “the Watcher turns his eyes away in resignation” while describing “Ships at a distance [that] have every man’s wish on board.” In this novel, which was written while its author was on a Guggenheim fellowship in Haiti, the protagonist exclaims “So this was a marriage!” as she muses on a blossoming (*) pear tree at the age of sixteen. This novel is framed as a conversation with Pheoby Watson, during which the protagonist recounts shooting her rabies-infected husband. Its title follows the line “They seemed to be staring at the dark” while the protagonist is sheltered from a hurricane with her lover Tea Cake. For 10 points, name this novel about Janie Crawford by Zora Neale Hurston.
tossups.answer: Their Eyes Were Watching God <RK, Long Fiction>

tossups.text: Michael Chandler and Christopher Lalonde’s studies of this practice among First Nations suggests that it is “hedged” against by “cultural continuity.” The classification of this practice as “monomania” was dismissed by a thinker who studied the “different aptitude” of countries for it. That thinker considered this practice an example of a “sui generis” phenomenon and suggested that “free inquiry” led to it being more common among (*) Protestants than Catholics. Except among Asian-Americans, the frequency of this practice in the US is about three times higher for men than for women. Altruistic, egoistic, and anomic motivations for this practice were distinguished by a pioneering French sociologist. For 10 points, name this practice studied by Émile Durkheim (“ay-MEEL dur-KEM”) whose historical varieties include suttee (“SUH-tee”).
tossups.answer: suicide [or equivalents like killing oneself; prompt on death; do not accept or prompt on “murder”] <WA, Social Science: Socio/Anthro>

tossups.text: A politically-conscious poet known as the “nightingale of” this country wrote the collection The Golden Threshold. In the 1960s, a group of poets in this country known as the Hungry Generation were visited by Ernesto Cardenal and Octavio Paz. A poet wrote a song promising “Victory, victory, victory to” the “dispenser of [this country’s] destiny,” whom he calls the “ruler of the minds of all people.” That poet beckoned “Father, let [this country] awake” in a place “Where the (*) mind is without fear and the head is held high” in a poem from a Nobel-Prize-winning collection with an introduction by W. B. Yeats (“yates”). That collection from this country begins “Thou hast made me endless, such is thy pleasure” and is translated as Song Offerings. For 10 points, name this home country of the Bengali poet Rabindranath Tagore.
tossups.answer: India [or Republic of India; or Bhārat Gaṇarājya] (The first poet is Sarojini Naidu.) <RK, Poetry>

tossups.text: This poem’s final line provides the title of a Clifford Odets play about a love triangle between Earl, Jerry, and May, which Fritz Lang adapted into a film. This poem was written shortly after its author married Frances Wightman, who is the implied addressee of its line “Come to the window, sweet is the night-air!” This poem likens religion to an entity that “Lay like the folds of a bright girdle furled,” but retreated to expose “the vast edges drear / And naked (*) shingles of the world,” giving off a “melancholy, long, withdrawing roar” in the process. tossups.text: These proteins are the substrate for a family of enzymes inhibited by vorinostat. Class III examples of those enzymes that modify these proteins lack a zinc cofactor and are called sirtuins (“sir-TOO-ins”). A domain unique to these proteins contains 3 alpha helices and two loops and allow them to form dimers through a handshake. David Allis and Michael Grunstein won the 2019 Lasker Award for decoding the effects of post-translational modifications on these proteins’ tails, often called their namesake code. These proteins are rich in (*) lysine and arginine residues, which are often methylated or acetylated. One of these proteins binds to linker DNA. Four different types of these highly conserved proteins are combined to form the nucleosome, which in turn binds to scaffolding proteins to form chromatin. For 10 points, DNA wraps around what highly basic packaging proteins?
tossups.answer: histones [prompt on nucleosome until read] <RN, Biology: Genetics/Cell>

tossups.text: Epithelioid examples of these cells fuse to form multi-nucleated giant cells in granulomatous (“gran-yuh-LOM-uh-tuss”) diseases like sarcoidosis. These cells use heme oxygenase to generate biliverdin, a critical step in red blood cell breakdown in the spleen. Whether these cells metabolize arginine to ornithine is used to categorize them into M1 and M2 subtypes, and like their precursors, they express CD68. Alveolar (“al-vee-OH-lur”) examples of these cells are reservoirs for (*) Mycobacterium tuberculosis. These cells are often characterized by the tissue they reside in, and are also known as microglia in the CNS and Kupffer cells in the liver. Like dendritic cells and B cells, these cells present antigens to T cells. For 10 points, name these cells produced by the differentiation of monocytes, whose name means “big eater.”
tossups.answer: macrophages [prompt on white blood cells or leukocytes or monocytes] <RN, Biology: Immuno>  If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions.   Bonuses

tossups.text: One story claims that this goddess came from Hyperborea (“hyper-bore-ee-uh”) with a great pack of wolves, which Antonius Liberalis connected to her journey to Lycia. When this goddess was depleted, Themis aided her by bringing nectar and ambrosia from heaven. Callimachus’s fourth hymn describes this goddess’s travels through Thessaly, after which she went to a place anchored by four granite pillars sent by Poseidon. After this goddess’s lover turned her into a quail and (*) impregnated her, she was chased by the Python across Greece. She wandered the world before coming to the island of Delos, as Hera had forbidden her from giving birth on solid land after her affair with Zeus. Niobe boasted of giving birth to more children than, for 10 points, what mother of the twin deities Apollo and Artemis?
tossups.answer: Leto <WA, Myths/Legends>

tossups.text: For a plasma, this quantity is proportional to the square root of the quantity [read slowly] “adiabatic index times charge state times electron temperature divided by the ratio of ion mass to proton mass.” A horizontal layer in which this quantity is minimized is the SOFAR channel. For a fluid, this quantity is equal to the square root of the ratio of its bulk modulus divided by its density. A common classroom setup to measure this quantity uses a (*) transparent pipe, blocked at one end with a piston and filled with a small amount of fine powder, known as Kundt’s tube. This quantity can be calculated as 331 plus 0.6 times the temperature in degrees Celsius. The ratio of an object’s velocity to this quantity is known as its Mach number. For 10 points, name this quantity that is equal to about 343 meters per second at room temperature.
tossups.answer: speed of sound [prompt on speed; accept Mach 1 until “Mach” is read; do not accept or prompt on “velocity” or “velocity of sound”] <RN, Physics>

tossups.text: Bartolomé Arzáns de Orsúa (“ar-SAHNS de or-SOO-ah”) recounts an incident in which he felt nauseous after being peer pressured into consuming this good by miners who said that not doing so would ruin their metal. A president from the Movement to Socialism developed a slogan saying “yes to” this crop, which he formerly farmed. Since 2000, campaigns against this good using drones to spray glyphosate (“GLY-fuh-sate”) from the air have brualized peasants who grow it. John Stith (*) Pemberton combined a west African nut with this good to form the name of his most famous invention. This crop was used as a stimulant by miners at Potosí in Bolivia, whose current president, Evo Morales, is an enthusiastic promoter of chewing it. For 10 points, name this crop that Pablo Escobar processed into a drug often sourced from Colombia.
tossups.answer: coca leaves [accept cocaine; prompt on Coca-Cola; do not accept “cocoa” or “cacao”] <JM, World History>
